One in five adults in the U.S. experiences a mental illness in a given year.
47.6 million adults in the U.S. experienced a mental illness in 2020, representing 18% of the U.S. adult population.
More than half of American adults with a mental illness do not receive treatment.
Serious mental illness costs America $193.2 billion in lost earnings per year.
13 million Americans live with a "serious" mental illness, more than the combined populations of New York and Los Angeles.
Depression affects an estimated 300 million people worldwide.
Anxiety disorders concern almost 4% of the world's population.
A patient is diagnosed with dementia symptoms every 3 seconds worldwide.
The annual cost of dementia is expected to more than double to $2 trillion by 2030.
10% of children and teenagers suffer from a clinically diagnosable mental illness.
Half of all lifetime mental health conditions begin by age 14.
75% of all lifetime mental health conditions begin by age 24.
Members of the LGBTQ+ community are almost 3 times more likely to experience a mental health condition such as major depression or generalized anxiety disorder.
Depression is the leading cause of disability worldwide.
More than 1 in 4 adults living with serious mental illnesses also struggles with substance abuse.
Women are nearly twice as likely to suffer from major depression than men.
Four times as many men than women commit suicide, but women attempt suicide more often than men.
Approximately 1% of Americans are affected by schizophrenia.
About 18% of people ages 18-54 have an anxiety disorder in a given year.
The first symptoms of OCD often begin during childhood or adolescence.
Social phobia typically begins in childhood or adolescence.
Exercise can improve sexual arousal responses in women taking antidepressants.
A single 40-minute walk per day at an average pace can burn up to 220 calories.
On average, a person walks 70,000 miles in their lifetime.
For every pound of muscle gained, the body burns 50 extra calories every day.
Aerobic exercise leads to neuron generation, which acts as a buffer to reduce effects of dementia and increase cognitive performance.
People who begin consistently exercising experience benefits like more energy, clearer thinking, improved sleep, and better moods.
Less than one-quarter (24%) of children 6 to 17 years of age participate in 60 minutes of physical activity every day.
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2021

fact: In 2017, only 26.1% of high school students participated in at least 60 minutes per day of physical activity on all 7 days of the previous week.
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2021

fact: In 2017, 51.1% of high school students participated in muscle strengthening exercises on 3 or more days during the previous week.
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2021
